etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Robert Kaye Greville (1794–1866), botanist. From classical Latin pulvīnātus cushion-shaped, in scientific Latin also moderately convex from pulvīnus cushion + -ātus

definitions: Resembling a cushion in shape, moderately convex.
Of a leaf or leaflet: having a pulvinus; = pulvinated.
